  14. (**************************************************************************)

  16. (* An abstract domain for dataflow analysis.  Defines a type [t]
  17.    of abstractions, with lattice operations. *)

  19. module type DOMAIN = sig
  20. ‌  type t
  21. ‌  val bot: t
  22. ‌  val join: t -> t -> t
  23. ‌  val lessequal: t -> t -> bool
  24. end

  26. (* Build a backward dataflow analysis engine for the given domain. *)

  28. module Backward(D: DOMAIN) : sig

  30.   val analyze: ?exnhandler: (D.t -> D.t) ->
  31.                ?exnescape: D.t ->
  32.                transfer: (Mach.instruction -> next: D.t -> exn: D.t -> D.t) ->
  33.                Mach.instruction ->
  34.                D.t * (int -> D.t)

  36.   (* [analyze ~exnhandler ~transfer instr] performs a backward dataflow
  37.      analysis on the Mach instruction [instr], typically a function body.

  39.      It returns a pair of
  40.      - the abstract state at the function entry point;
  41.      - a mapping from catch handler label to the abstract state at the
  42.        beginning of the handler with this label.

  44.      The [transfer] function is called as [transfer i ~next ~exn].
  45.      - [i] is a sub-instruction of [instr].
  46.      - [next] is the abstract state "after" the instruction for
  47.        normal control flow, falling through the successor(s) of [i].
  48.      - [exn] is the abstract state "after" the instruction for
  49.        exceptional control flow, branching to the nearest exception handler
  50.        or exiting the function with an unhandled exception.

  52.      The [transfer] function, then, returns the abstract state "before"
  53.      the instruction.  The dataflow analysis will, then, propagate this
  54.      state "before" as the state "after" the predecessor instructions.

  56.      For compound instructions like [Iifthenelse], the [next] abstract
  57.      value that is passed to [transfer] is not the abstract state at
  58.      the end of the compound instruction (e.g. after the "then" and "else"
  59.      branches have joined), but the join of the abstract states at
  60.      the beginning of the sub-instructions.  More precisely:
  61.      - for [Iifthenelse(tst, ifso, ifnot)], it's the join of the
  62.        abstract states at the beginning of the [ifso] and [ifnot]
  63.        branches;
  64.      - for [Iswitch(tbl, cases)], it's the join of the abstract states
  65.        at the beginning of the [cases] branches;
  66.      - for [Icatch(recflag, body, handlers)] and [Itrywith(body, handler)],
  67.        it's the abstract state at the beginning of [body].

  69.      The [transfer] function is called for every sub-instruction of [instr],
  70.      as many times as needed to reach a fixpoint.  Hence, it can record
  71.      the results of the analysis at each sub-instruction in a mutable
  72.      data structure.  For instance, the transfer function for liveness
  73.      analysis updates the [live] fields of instructions as a side
  74.      effect.

  76.      The optional [exnhandler] argument deals with exception handlers.
  77.      This is a function that transforms the abstract state at the
  78.      beginning of an exception handler into the exceptional abstract
  79.      state for the instructions within the body of the handler.
  80.      Typically, for liveness analysis, it takes the registers live at
  81.      the beginning of the handler and removes the register
  82.      [Proc.loc_exn_bucket] that carries the exception value.  If not
  83.      specified, [exnhandler] defaults to the identity function.

  85.      The optional [exnescape] argument deals with unhandled exceptions.
  86.      It is the abstract state corresponding to exiting the function on an
  87.      unhandled exception.  It defaults to [D.bot].
  88.   *)

  90. end
